content.title: Energy Access - Core Concepts
content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

In this lesson, we establish a global perspective on energy access. You will discover why energy access is a fundamental human right and how it is essential for breaking the cycle of poverty. We will delve into the nuances between energy access and inclusive energy services, highlighting the importance of equitable energy distribution to ensure that no one is left behind. Finally, you will explore the main types of energy uses and applications, providing you with a comprehensive vision of the energy landscape.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: energy access
concepts.body: Energy access refers to the ability of individuals and communities to obtain reliable and affordable energy services, such as electricity and clean cooking fuels, necessary for their daily activities and economic development.

concepts.title: fundamental energy needs
concepts.body: The basic requirements for energy that are essential for human survival and well-being, including energy for heating, cooking, lighting, and basic transportation.

concepts.title: inclusive energy services
concepts.body: Inclusive energy services refer to energy solutions that are accessible, affordable, and equitable for all individuals and communities, particularly marginalized or underserved populations, ensuring that everyone can benefit from reliable energy access.

content.text: The 2024 SDG 7 Tracking Report reveals a concerning trend: for the first time in ten years, electricity access is lagging behind population growth. This translates to an estimated 10 million more people lacking electricity, bringing the total to 685 million globally (WB, 2024) While progress has been made, clean cooking access remains stagnant, with 2.1 billion people still relying on harmful methods such as traditional biomass, charcoal, and kerosene, which contribute to indoor air pollution and gender inequities. Globally, 1.2 billion people lack adequate access to cooling, putting at risk their ability to survive extreme heat, store nutritious food, and safely receive vaccines (SE4All, 2022) Moreover, 1.18 billion people are energy poor (UNDP, 2024). Recent studies highlight a crucial aspect: energy poverty often persists even near established grids. This underscores the diverse types of energy needs and highlights the multifaceted nature of the challenge. Indeed, proximity to energy infrastructure doesnâ€™t guarantee access to it, or the ability to use it for fundamental needs

content.title: Part 1: Energy Access as an enabler of Human Rights

content.text: Part 1 Overview

Access to energy and inclusive energy services are essential drivers of social progress and economic growth. They are deeply intertwined with other human rights related to health, food security, livelihoods and education.

Access to energy is foundational to modern life and sustainable development, yet it remains unevenly distributed across the globe. According to the IEA, over 685 million people still lacked access to electricity in 2021, with 2.08 billion people relying on polluting fuels for cooking (ESMAP, 2024). Sustainable Development Goal 7 (SDG 7) seeks to address this gap by ensuring access to affordable, reliable, sustainable, and modern energy for all by 2030. However, while universal energy access is clearly recognized as essential for development, it is not formally recognized as a standalone human right in international law. This presents a challenge for accountability and enforcement, as the absence of energy services is a significant barrier to the realization of many fundamental human rights.
The role of Energy in fulfilling the Universal Declaration of Human Rights

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR), adopted in 1948, outlines fundamental rights that are directly and indirectly dependent on modern energy services, such as the rights to an adequate standard of living, health, education, and security. The milestone document emphasizes that human rights are interdependent and indivisible. This means that fulfilling one right often depends on the realization of others, and energy access plays a critical enabling role in this web of rights.
Right to an Adequate Standard of Living

Article 25 of the UDHR enshrines the right to an adequate standard of living, which includes housing, food, health care, and social services. Energy is essential to all of these components. Electricity powers homes, enables safe lighting, supports refrigeration for food and medicines, and is critical for operating household appliances that allow for hygiene and well-being. Modern cooking solutions reduce indoor air pollution, currently causing an estimated 3.2 million deaths annually, of which 237,000 were among children under age 5 (WHO., 2024). Without access to clean and reliable energy, the right to an adequate standard of living can be severely compromised.
Right to Life, Liberty and Security

The right to life, liberty, and security (Article 3 of the UDHR) is also closely interlinked with energy access. Electricity is vital for health services, as it enables hospitals to function and life-saving medical equipment to operate. Emergency services and early warning systems for environmental hazards also rely on energy to function effectively. Moreover, energy contributes to public safety thanks to street lighting and household lighting, both of which contribute to reducing crime particularly in urban and peri-urban areas. Reliance on traditional fuels also heightens the risk of violence, particularly for women and girls who, in conflict-affected areas and refugee camps, face increased exposure to gender-based violence during long trips to collect firewood
Right to Equality

Energy access also intersects with the right to equality (Article 1 of the UDHR), as energy poverty exacerbates existing social and economic inequalities. Marginalized groups, such as women, people living in rural areas, and Indigenous communities, are disproportionately affected by the lack of access to modern energy. This inequality can have cascading negative effects across sectors, limiting opportunities for education, health, and employment. In many parts of the world, women spend up to 18 hours weekly collecting fuel for cooking, while children may have to skip school to assist - time that could otherwise be spent for education or earning income, thus reinforcing cycles of poverty and gender inequality (UNDP, 2024).
Right to Education

Education, presented in Article 26 of the UDHR, is another area where energy access plays an enabling role. Students need lighting to study at home in the evening, while schools require electricity to power digital learning tools and maintain internet connectivity. The COVID-19 pandemic made this need especially evident, as remote learning became the norm in many regions, highlighting the digital divide exacerbated by energy poverty. Without electricity, millions of children around the world were unable to continue their education and were delayed in their learning process. Given the importance of energy access to realize fundamental and internationally recognized human rights, it is important that energy policies and programs are designed to empower individuals and communities to claim their rights and participate fully in social, economic, and political life. As the global community works toward SDG 7, there is a critical need to recognize energy beyond just infrastructure, as a foundation for dignity, equality, and human development.

The vicious cycle of poverty and lack of energy access is a self-reinforcing loop where each issue perpetuates the other. Without reliable energy, households miss out on educational and economic opportunities. This situation particularly affects women and girls, who often bear the burden of household responsibilities, such as cooking and collecting fuel. Without energy, these tasks become time-consuming, limiting their potential for economic development. These conditions reduce income, trapping people in poverty. The lack of income, in turn, prevents access to energy, perpetuating the cycle of deprivation and reinforcing existing gender inequalities.

content.title: Part 2: Definitions of energy access and inclusive energy services

content.text: Part 2 Overview
Energy access, energy services and inclusive energy services. These concepts are related but distinct. Do you know the difference? This is described to follow.
Ensuring that no one is left behind

In this module we explore the concept of energy access from an international development perspective. More specifically, we are concerned with ensuring access to the fundamental energy services that individuals and communities rely upon to ensure their well-being, comfort, safety, and productivity.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Fundamental energy needs and applications

content.text: Electricity

Electricity stands out as a fundamental energy need due to its unparalleled versatility, reliability, and indispensability in modern life. Unlike other forms of energy, electricity serves as a versatile carrier that can power an extensive range of appliances and technologies. It powers essential aspects of daily life, from lighting and communication to education, healthcare, and economic activities.
Clean Cooking

Having access to clean fuels, such as biogas, liquified petroleum gas (LPG) or electricity and efficient cooking appliances is a fundamental energy need with far-reaching implications for health, environment, and socio-economic development. In many parts of the world, especially in regions confronting multidimensional poverty, traditional cooking methods using solid fuels such as wood, coal, or biomass are common, contributing to indoor air pollution. Clean cooking fuels coupled with more efficient appliances like induction stoves or clean cookstoves offer a transformative solution to this challenge.
Heating and Cooling

Heating and cooling are essential for maintaining comfortable living conditions, particularly in extreme climates. Traditional heating methods using fossil fuels or wood contribute to air pollution, deforestation and climate change. Cleaner alternatives like electricity or sustainably sourced biomass, coupled with energy-efficient appliances, can improve indoor air quality, public health, and environmental sustainability. Additionally, cooling needs, including refrigeration for food storage, are crucial for maintaining food safety and quality, especially with rising demand for cooling due to climate change and rising global temperatures.
Household energy use

Energy in households is critical for performing everyday tasks. Reliable energy access powers water heating and pumping, which are crucial for sanitation and hygiene, supporting WASH (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene) services in households, schools, and community centers. Access to clean water and proper sanitation, made possible through energy, is directly linked to public health and gender equality, particularly in education, where girls are disproportionately affected by inadequate WASH facilities. Additionally, energy supports household automation and appliances, such as washing machines that alleviate manual labor. Access to energy also facilitates remote work and online education bridging connectivity gaps and enhancing quality of life.
Community & institutions use of energy

Community and institutions are the essential services (such as schools, hospitals and community spaces) that keep a community functioning. Reliable energy access in these public spaces and institutions supports safety, improves services delivery, promotes social cohesion and drives economic and social progress. This includes public lighting for safety and security after dark, as well as well-lit and public transportation system that is crucial for mobility and economic activity. Community energy projects such as water distribution, clean cooking in schools, community fridges, or internet centers can serve as key demonstration points for scalable energy access solutions, amplifying their impact on broader society.
Productive use of energy

Productive use of energy refers to the application of energy to activities that enhance livelihoods, improve economic output, or generate income. It is a cornerstone for breaking the cycle of poverty. Access to energy boosts income and productivity. Whether it's powering irrigation systems for agriculture, running equipment for local businesses, or supporting manufacturing processes, productive energy use helps communities thrive economically and socially. It enhances the profitability of micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs). For example, an electric sewing machine or a milk cooling tank for farmers can significantly improve production and income. This allows entrepreneurs to employ others or invest in better health and education for their families.

To ensure a sustainable future, it is crucial to recognize and guarantee the fundamental energy needs of every individual. Each of these needs plays a vital role in enhancing the quality of life and promoting development. It is also essential to consider the entire spectrum of energy applications required for human well-being. By addressing multiple applications of energy services, we can significantly enhance the outcomes of energy interventions.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Global data shows huge disparities in energy access, raising concerns about human development. Energy access powers essential human rights and breaking the poverty cycle canâ€™t be achieved without it.

The concepts of energy access and inclusive energy services are very specific to universal energy access because their focus goes beyond simply adding more energy services. Rather, these services need to be planned carefully in order to ensure no one is left behind.
Recognizing and addressing the full spectrum of fundamental energy needs and applications is essential for improving quality of life and truly promoting development.
